div.p: > Joyce Farrell: Hi.
This is Joyce Farrell.
In this video, we're going

to structure some
unstructured logic.
The three structures

in structured programming are
sequence, selection, and loop.

In sequence, one of
them follows the other,

with a selection a
question is asked and one

of two logical paths is
traveled, and with a loop,

a question is asked and
while the question continues

to be true, the loop body
continues to execute.

The three structures,
sequence, selection, and loop,

can be used to solve
any programming problem.

You must combine them by
stacking them or nesting them,

but if you get the
right combinations,

every programming problem can be
solved using just these three.

Let's take a look at an
unstructured flowchart segment.

In this unstructured
segment, there's a process
"G" followed by a question "H".

If "H" is no, there's
a process "J".

If "H" is yes, there's
a question "I",

and "I" performs
either "J" or "K".

Let's take this unstructured
segment and make it structured.

Start with the first
step, which is step "G".
"G" is a sequence.

It's a sequence of
only one step.

A sequence might have
two, three, five, twenty,

any number of steps, but
as long as there are steps

with no chances to branch
away, you have a sequence.

After "G" in the flowchart,
the next item is question "H".

"H" is the beginning
of a selection.

When "H" is no, "J"
executes, and that's fine.
That's half of a selection.

When "H" is yes, another
question executes, question "I".
That's fine.

You can have a selection
structure nested inside a
selection structure,

so selection "I" is going to
be nested inside selection "H".

When "I" is no, however,
you can't proceed
to the existing step "J".

That would violate the integrity
of the "I" selection structure,
so you repeat "J".

When "I" is no, you
execute the same steps
that you execute when "H" is no.

When "I" is yes, you
execute step "K",

then you can join
together the "I" selection,

and then finally you join
together the "H" selection,

and the "I" selection is nested
entirely inside the "H" selection.

Let's compare the
two flowcharts,

the original unstructured
version

and the newly structured
version.

In both cases, the first
step to execute is "G".

When "H" is asked
if the answer is no,

both flowcharts
execute step "J".

If you start over and
do step "G" and ask "H"

but the answer is yes, in both
cases question "I" is asked.

When "I" is no, in both
cases step "J" executes.

If you start over and do step
"G" and ask "H" and ask "I",

if "I" is yes, in both
cases step "K" executes.

The two flowcharts do
exactly the same thing,

but the first one
is unstructured

and the second one
is structured.

Let's take a different
unstructured flowchart segment.

In this case, there's step
"L" followed by question "M",

and if "M" is yes, you do step
"N" then do step "L" again.

Well, step "L" by
itself is fine.
That is part of the sequence.
After "L", you ask "M".
"M" is starting a loop.

When the loop is
yes, you do step "N",
and then you do step "L".

The loop has to repeat step "L"
so that the logic after step

"L" can travel right
back to question "M".
So the loop has "M",

and it contains a
sequence of "N" and "L".

Let's compare the original
and the structured version.

In both cases, you perform
step "L", then you ask "M".

If the answer to "M" is
yes, you do step "N",

and in both cases
you then do step "L".

After "L", you always
ask "M" again.

If "M" is yes, you do "N"
and "L", and ask "M" again.
If "M" is no, the logic ends.

Both flowcharts
do the same thing,

but the first one
is unstructured,
the second one is structured.
Thanks for watching.
